Sir,

Enclosed find vouchers in favour of John H. Hager amounting to ten dollars, for articles supplied the school trustees for their annual school picnic.

It has been the custom of the band for a good many years to hold an annual picnic for the children, for which the council has voted ten dollars to purchase prizes, candies, nuts etc., for the children. At the regular meeting in July this grant was overlooked but the council and trustees decided to hold the picnic as usual and came out here the day before the picnic. I told them then they should have obtained the sanction of the Department before getting the articles, they thought as it had always been the custom there could be no objection now. However in future authority will first be obtained before any expense is incurred.

I would therefore recommend that a cheque be sent here in Mr. Hager's favour for the amount.

Your Obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

D. S. G. of I. A.

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

COUNCIL MEETING OF THE MISSISSAGUAS OF THE CREDIT, MAY 17, 1916.

Moved by James A. Wood seconded by Frank King that we ask permission to erect a new fence along the easterly side of the council house grounds and get a new gate for the entrance to school grounds. If permission is granted the Agent to prepare specifications for the same and ask for tenders and let the contract as soon as convenient.

Carried unanimously.

Certified correct.

W. E. Van Loon,
Agent.

Hagersville, May 19, 1916.
Ottawa, May 25th., 1916.

Sir,

With reference to resolution recently passed by the Council of the Mississaugas of the Credit, I beg to say that the Department approves of the proposal to erect a fence along the easterly side of the Council House grounds and obtain a new gate for the entrance to the school grounds. Tenders for the work required to be done may be called for and when they are received, they should be submitted to the Department when a contract will be awarded for the work. You should furnish the Department with specifications of the work and with an estimate of cost, when you send in the tenders.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLennan
Acting Deputy and Secretary.

W.C. Van Loon Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hagersville, Ont.
Specifications of material and labour required for the erection and completion of sixty rods of woven wire fence along the easterly side of the council house grounds, situated on the southerly half of Lot number 6 in the second concession of the township of Tuscarora, county of Brant.

Said fence to have eight strands of woven wire (No9) with upright stays not more than twenty two inches apart, to be firmly fastened to anchor posts well and substantially set, properly braced. Anchor and all other posts to be of good sound cedar, set not more than two rods a part and three feet or more in the ground. Woven wire to be well fastened to every post with suitable staples.

Provide and put in position a gate about three feet in width at the entrance to the school grounds.

The contractor to furnish all material, labour, tools and everything necessary to complete the fence in a good substantial manner and satisfactory to the Agent or Inspector in charge, and completed within one month from from date of signing this agreement.

[Signature]

Sir:

On receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, I at once prepared specifications and asked for tenders for building 60 rods of fence and putting in a new gate at the entrance to the school grounds.

I received the following tenders.

Julius King, 53.00. Wm. King 48.00
David W. Laform 49.50 Walter Sault, 50.00

The two senior councillors, James A. Wood and W.H. Sterling called here on Saturday and we decided to recommend the offer of Wm. King as he has done considerable fence building and lives within one half mile of the place.

If this meets with the approval of the Department King will start the work as soon as we receive a reply.

I will enclose the tenders, also a copy of the specifications.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, June 16, 1916.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant enclosing copy of specifications and tenders for the erection of a fence along the easterly side of the Council House grounds and putting in a new gate at the entrance to the New Credit school grounds.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

Minutes of Council Meeting held in the Council House of the Mississaugas of the Credit, March 31st, 1917.

Moved by Chief King seconded by John Herkimer that we procure eight yards of gravel to grade around walks and out buildings at the school house.

Carried unanimously.

W. C. Van Loon

Hagersville,
March 23rd, 1917.

Sir,

Along the walks leading to the school house and out buildings the ground is low and wet and it is a hard matter to keep the floor of the school house clean as the children cannot get around this low wet ground very well. We estimated that eight yards of gravel would be sufficient put it in good condition. I think we can get it delivered for $1.25 per yard as that is the price we paid last fall.

W. C. Van Loon
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 30, 1917.

Sir,

In reference to your letter of the 23rd instant I beg to say that the Department approves of the resolution passed by the Council of the Mississaugas of the Credit to procure eight yards of gravel to grade around the walks and outbuildings at the New Credit School.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. O. VanLoon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hagersville, Ont.
Mississaugas of the Credit.

Sir,

A new foundation is needed under the wood shed at the school house; the building is in very good condition except the foundation, and we have the gravel on the ground for that, all is required is the cement and labour, if this is approved of by the Department I will prepare specifications and ask for tenders in the regular way.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, November 26th, 1917.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st, inst., forwarding a minute of Council in regard to placing a new foundation under the wood shed at the School house.

Before considering this resolution the Department desires you to submit an estimate of the cost of making this improvement.

Your obedient servant

Sir:

It was reported to me on Thursday that the school house at New Credit had been slightly damaged by fire on the previous evening.

I drove out and learned that some time after school had been closed, about 6 o'clock P.M., fire was seen through the windows, which was quickly put out after burning a small hole through the floor.

It appears that fire by some means fell from the small door at the front, which the draft is regulated, rolled off the metal platform and a hole through the floor so that the legs of the stove fell through and caused part of the pipe to fall.

I at once notified the local insurance agent. He advised me to value the damage and get it made good and would notify the Insurance Company. I sent a man with the necessary material from here yesterday and had it made good so that school can be opened again on Monday.

The loss will be paid to the Department and as soon as I hear from the Company I will send down the account for repairs and report fully in the matter.

Sir:

When visiting the school at New Credit yesterday I was informed by the teacher that the water in the well was not fit for the children to drink and they had to go about one quarter of a mile for water.

I examined the well along with some of the councillors and found that a new pump was needed; the old one has been there for a good many years, broken and repaired many times and the iron pipes appear to be rusted through in places, and the well should be cleaned out. I think a rabbit or cat has been drowned in it during the winter, one of the boards was loose and had been left open.

I enquired the probable cost of a new outfit this morning and was told by Mr. Shildrick who sells pumps that a good cast iron pump head with brass cylinder, galvanized iron pipe, put in complete would cost $24.75; if an iron cylinder was used it would be $6.00 less. He recommends brass and so would I after using both.

His estimate is given on a well 20 feet deep; I do not think this well is that deep, if any less the cost of the amount of extra pipe would be added or deducted.

It would take two men about one day to clean the well as it is about full of water at the present time.

This is a matter that should be attended to without delay.

Your Obedient Servant,

Sir:-

I was out yesterday to visit the school and to see what was required to the school house to make the repairs mentioned in your letter of the 30th Oct. No. 16-1-5. It does not require much to make the corners of the building good which have been damaged by reason of the conductor pipes being broken off and water allowed to run down near the brick wall. The Council house needs considerable more repairs than the school house; some of the bricks torn out and all conductor pipes both at the school and council house are broken off halfway up the sides of buildings.

I think if new elbows are put on above the reaches of children, to throw the water away from the buildings is all that would be required after the corners have been repaired. I think about one yard of sand and one barrel of cement would be plenty for everything and it would take a mason about one half day to do the necessary work. Sir.—
Referring to your letter of Janv23,1923, with which you returned an account from the James Shildrick Estate, with a request for me to state what articles were used for.

I beg to say in reply that John Secord was caretaker of the school house for the year 1921, he was ordered by the trustees to get the necessary bolts and screws to repair the seats and fasten them to the floor.

Sub Section 2 of Section 5 of By-law No.12 give the trustees authority to get such work done.

The council refused to pay the whole account as Secord according to the account, ordered four gross of screws which could not have been used for this job, as the 2 doz ordered in the first place was plenty for what was done. He also purchased a screw driver, which was not left on the premises.

Mr. Shildrick tells me that Secord did get four gross of screws and said they were needed for the seats at the school house. Secord does not deny getting them but could not tell what he done with them. He should be made to pay for them out of his next spring's interest money.

I have struck them off the bill by request of the Council, we will try and get Secord at the next council meeting to explain matters.

The irregularity of many of the pupils could be remedied if a bell was provided. At present it is out of repair.

The truant laws are not enforced. It would make the work of the teacher easier if the parents showed more interest in the education of their children and the laws mentioned above were enforced.

Laura Evelyn Garrett,

Ottawa, April 5th, 1924.

Sir:

The teacher of the New Credit Indian Day School, in her annual report for the fiscal year ended March 31st last, states that the irregularity in attendance of many of the pupils could be remedied if a bell was provided. At present it is out of repair. Please report regarding the condition of the bell on hand, and the cost of repairing the same, or, if necessary, the procuring of a new bell.

The teacher further states that sufficient attention is not given to cases of truancy, and she asks that the laws regarding same be enforced. If there is a truant officer, you should take this matter up with him and see that he attends more faithfully to his duties and that all children of school age, who are in good health, attend regularly each day school is in operation.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. C. Van Loon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hagersville, Ont.

Sir,

I am enclosing vouchers in favour of Risdill's Bakery amounting to $5.50 for refreshments for the annual school picnic held at New Credit on June 14th.

And one in favour of Mrs. F.R. Speich amounting to $9.50 for prizes for the different classes and for those who were successful in the various games.

The question of holding the school picnic came up at the regular council meeting in May last and it was moved by councillor Chas. W. Sault and seconded by Norman A. King that we ask for the usual grant of $15.00 and carried unanimously.

When writing the proceedings in my minute book from notes taken at the meeting I overlooked this resolution consequently it was not included in extracts sent to the Department.

The Trustees and council thought it was best to hold picnic early so that the Missionary and teacher could both be with them; the Missionary is leaving at the end of this month and we do not know yet whether we will have the same teacher after the holidays or not.

Moved by P. J. Laform, seconded by Chief King that we ask that shingles and nails be purchased to put a new roof on the old school house, now used for public purposes, with the understanding that members of the band will do the work without cost.

Carried unanimously.

Hagersville, May 26th, 1925.

The old school house was placed near the Council house and used for public purposes for the band and for the last two or three years the Dunkers, a religious sect, have been holding meetings there. The roof should be reshingled and as the members of the band have agreed to do the work for nothing it should be done.

I have not the exact size of the roof but think it would require seven or eight thousand shingles.

W.C. Van Loom.
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 4th, 1925.

Sir:

Referring to resolution of the Council of the Mississaugas of the Credit Band held on the 20th ultimo regarding the reshingling of the old school house which is now used for public purposes, I beg to say that the Department will approve of this resolution.

You should arrange for the purchase of the quantity of shingles required. Competitive prices should be obtained and the shingles purchased from the firm quoting you the lowest price. It is understood that the members of the Band will do the work without any charge to the Department. You should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the shingles. You should arrange to have this work done at an early date.

Regarding the resolution that a grant of $20 be allowed from Band funds to purchase prizes, refreshments and music for the annual school picnic, I beg to say that this resolution is approved. You should furnish properly certified vouchers covering the expenditure incurred for the purpose.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the New Credit Indian Day School, makes the following remarks regarding the work which he states should be carried out:

"Brick school house and Council house are situated on same grounds. The woodshed is in need of repair; the roof is bad, also siding. The grass should be cut soon. The school building needs some painting with cement plaster. The rain pipe leads to the ground are missing. Therefore, the rain is destroying foundation in two places as well as one corner of the building. Flower beds have been started, some fertilizer or wood soil should be furnished to the beds. Some window panes need repair. Some seats need repair."

I shall be pleased to hear from you regarding the suggestions made by the Inspector, and you should state the cost of carrying out any of the work mentioned by him. An early reply is desired, in order that, if it is decided to have all the repairs as mentioned by the Inspector carried out, the work could be done during the coming summer holidays.

You may arrange to have the grass cut on the school grounds, and if any fertilizer is required for the flower beds, you may supply same.

Your obedient servant,

MEMO.

Sir-

We have had no rain to amount to anything since May and things have become serious as far as water is concerned at the school and around New Credit where the school is there is not a drilled well the nearest is about two miles the children have been drinking water from the old well that is not fit for a beast to drink. The first intimation I had of this was Sat. I arranged for a man to get water twice a week in a can from the drilled well above mentioned until further advised at .50 cents a can.

My own candid opinion is that a well should be drilled at the school and this should be done immediately. I have had a report from the Doctor McCracken to that effect, I believe some of the school children are sick now.

I cannot give you an estimated cost of a well as I have no idea or no one else has how far we may have to drill but a rough guess would be around $125.00.

Kindly advise me as to this at your earliest possible date. I had intended sending a night letter, but since I have arranged for water to be drawn I have more time.

I had three of my councilmen in on Sat. and they think to only solution is the same as I have mentioned.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 3, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, relative to obtaining a supply of drinking water for the use of the New Credit Indian Day School.

In this connection I have to say that it is considered, as stated by you, the only solution is in having a well drilled. You may, therefore, arrange to employ competent labour for the purpose of drilling a well at a convenient spot near the school, and the cost, if possible, should be kept within the amount mentioned by you, viz., $125. After an expenditure to this amount has been made, if not sufficient to complete the well, you should report the progress to the Department and obtain authority for proceeding further with the work. It is hoped, however, that the above amount will cover the cost of drilling the well and installing the necessary pump and piping required, also a suitable platform around the well. You should arrange to have this work begin as soon as possible. It is hoped that a good supply of water can be obtained without it being necessary to drill to any great depth. Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred in the drilling of the well and in the purchase and installation of the pump, piping, etc., required. The Department will leave the matter of drilling the well in your hands to make the best arrangements and at the lowest possible expense.

It is noted that you have arranged in the meantime to have the drinking water required delivered at the school twice each week. Certified accounts, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred for this purpose.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Memorandum

Mr. Ferrier,

I visited the New Credit Indian Day School recently and found conditions generally very satisfactory.

Mrs. Parker is spoken very highly of as a teacher and apparently is very deeply interested in her work among the Indian children. Agent Winger states that the pupils are making excellent progress under her tuition.

The school buildings are in very good condition. The seats in the classroom are of the old double type, very badly worn. I would recommend that thirty new single seats be provided when funds are available.

There are some low spots around the building which hold the water and mud; pupils walking through these keep the entrance and classroom floor very dirty. A few loads of gravel, easily available, would eliminate this condition at little cost. I would recommend that this be done.

Mrs. Parker is paid $95.00 per teaching month; she has to keep a car to get to and from school. She has made an application through Agent Winger for an increase of $5.00 per month, which would make her equal with the Six Nations teachers. From what I saw of her work in the short visit to the school and from reports of some of the Indian parents, I would recommend this for your consideration.

Inspector.
Ottawa, February 26, 1931.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the New Credit Indian Day School, states that he found conditions generally very satisfactory and that the teacher is interested in the work and the pupils are making good progress.

The Inspector has drawn attention to the condition of the grounds around the building. He states that there are some low spots which hold water and mud, and the pupils walking through these keep the entrance and classroom floor very dirty. He recommends that a few loads of gravel, which he states is available, be placed around the grounds and at the entrance to the school, and states that this would overcome the condition at little cost. I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange as soon as weather conditions permit to have a few loads of gravel placed around the grounds and at the entrance to the school. You should see that same is properly levelled. No unnecessary expense should be incurred. After the gravel has been supplied, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The Inspector also states that the seats in the classroom are of the old double type, very badly worn, and recommends that 30 new single desks be provided. You may draw this matter to the attention of the Department early next Summer, and at that time you should give full particulars as to the size and number of each size of single desk required, also full shipping directions. It would be advisable to have each row of desks of the same size, with a front and rear seat. When we receive particulars regarding the desks as requested next Summer, consideration will then be given as to whether funds for the purpose can be provided or not.

Your obedient servant,

Maurice Winger, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hagersville,
Ont.

Sir—

With further information regarding fire which destroyed the New Credit Indian Day school. The fire occurred Sunday morning at about 8 o'clock. I was not notified until this morning Monday. I immediately went and made inquiries but could find very little information except the fire started in the roof on the same end as the chimney; there had been a snow fall Saturday evening but the first man at the fire claimed no tracks could be seen around the building so the only cause as far as we can figure must have been from the soot lying in the chimney and must have been there from Friday night.

The books were all saved also most of the small things such as water pails, globes, and extras used to carry on the school work. About the only requirements to carry on would be seats and a blackboard. For this I would recommend that we purchase new seats that would be used in a new building also a small blackboard that could also be used in a new building. Apart from that the cost to carry on would be very small. I could purchase whatever we need from our local hardware store and would not run over $10.00.

Should the Department decide to purchase new seats and put them temporary in the council house, it would have to be looked after from the Department or else instructions sent for the purchase of them. In that case the teacher could with myself and possibly the Inspector for this section make the selection. Approximate cost of these can be sent later.

I may add that the out buildings were all saved just the school burned and I have notified Mr. Jennings the Insurance agent here of the burning; it has $1000.00 on the building and $200.00 on the contents furniture etc.

Any further instructions advise me.

The Secretary,

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

The Indian Day School building and contents on the New Credit Reserve were totally destroyed by fire on the morning of the 11th instant. The local Agent was unable to state definitely how the fire occurred.

Thirty-six single school desks will be required, at a cost of approximately £250. Funds for the purpose can be provided from the item in the Estimates for Unforeseen Expenditure. Sir:

The agent for the New Credit Bay School requested me to write to you concerning the fire at that school.

I left the school house on Dec. 7 about 5 o'clock. The fire in the stove was then nearly out, as we had left the school at 3 o'clock to practice in the Council House for our Christmas Concert. I returned from the Council House about 4.45 and, as I have stated, the fire was nearly out. I left the school about 5 for my boarding house. Everything else was in good condition. We never had any large fire during the day, nor did we ever have any trouble with the chimney.
The cause of the fire is unknown to me. There is only one thing which may have caused it. The chimney was built from the foundation on up. It was also hollow from the foundation on up. This hollow part became filled with soot. In time the soot took fire which caused the roof to become heated and take fire also. Whether this is a good cause I can not say but to my knowledge it is the only cause of the fire.

This is all the information I can give, for as I returned Monday morning for work I found it in ruins. Just why it should take fire 46 hours after there was fire in the stove I can not say. My above explanation is the only cause that I know of.

Yours sincerely,

Winifred Backer
Teacher
Sir -

Replying to your letter dated Dec. 16th, I have consulted the teacher and different members of the band who were at the fire last Sunday morning of the burning of the school and everyone has the same story that the fire started in the roof around the chimney, they claim that no one was near the School form Friday night and the caretaker had the keys in his pocket from the time he locked the school about 5 o'clock Friday evening. When the first persons got to the school they tried the doors and everything was looked good they had to break in with a crowbar. So as for getting the origin of the fire it is impossible. I am of the same opinion as the Dept. I can hardly see how a fire could smoulder from Friday night until Sunday morning but we have no other proof, so for the present will have to believe the short story.

I have requested the teacher to write the Department direct any information he can give, which he has consented to do.

Ottawa, January 27th, 1933.

Sir,

I inspected the New Credit Agency on the 13th-14th instant and beg to submit the following brief report on conditions generally.

The one Indian Day School on the reserve was destroyed by fire in December last. A class-room has been fitted up with desks and necessary equipment in the Council Hall and meets the needs very well. There are 42 pupils on the roll, 27 present the day of my visit. The absentees were reported suffering from the flu. The pupils are given Cod Liver Oil daily. They have all been vaccinated up to date.

The classroom is too cold for the comfort and health of the pupils. They have to keep their coats on. This is due to an open balcony at one end of the classroom causing a draught. It would be unnecessary to go to the expense of boarding this up. A couple of our heavy gray army blankets hung across the opening would eliminate the trouble. When no longer needed, these could be given to some indigent Indians.

There is not sufficient blackboard in the classroom. Two pieces, 6 feet each, should be provided.

The Department is very fortunate in having the services of Wilfred Bacher as teacher. He is an excellent teacher, holds a First Class Certificate, deeply interested in Indian work. The pupils are making very satisfactory progress under his tuition.

Your obedient servant,

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector.

NEW CREDIT MINUTES OF COUNCIL MEETING HELD JAN. 17, 1934.

A motion was passed by Walter Sault and seconded by Chancey Herkimer that the band being very much handicapped for the use of their council house, immediate steps be taken to have a new school erected. The band being out of the use of this building for considerable time the Dept. should give this matter every consideration.

Carried.

Regarding the motion about the building of a new school the band have been dissatisfied all year not being able to use their council house as they have concerts and different entertainments during the year and have no place to hold them. They feel since the old building was covered partly by Insurance, they should have a new school. It would also provide a little work for them. I believe if a good contractor was engaged by the day and used as much Indian labour as possible the school would not have to cost too much money, especially in these times as labor can be got very cheap. It looks as though this is the time to build a school if they expect to have one at all.

Maurice Winger,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

Referring to resolution of the Council of the Mississaugas of the New Credit Band, held on the 17th instant, that a new school building be erected to replace the one destroyed by fire in December, 1932, I have to say that, owing to lack of funds, the Department will be unable to consider the erection of a new building at the present time. While a certain amount of insurance was obtained on the building that was burned, under the policy of the Department this sum would not be utilized in paying the cost of a new building. The money received on account of insurance has been placed to the credit of the funds of the Band.

The present arrangements for the carrying on of classroom activity in the council hall will have to be continued, until such time as it is possible to have the funds required in the erection of a new building provided by Parliament.

We the Mississauga Council of the Credit do hereby petition through your agency to the Indian Dept. of Affairs at Ottawa.

First:

John Crain Chief

Sir:

As for the school house I believe a petition is in the making from different bodies on the reserve, one being the Women's Institute complaining about the accommodation at the school for our children. A visit from some member of the Dept. to look these matters over would be appreciated so you could see the need of these two things. The road 1½ mile at a cost of $1800.00 and also a new school and they would both be permanent improvements.

To the Educational Welfare Office Ottawa

Sir,

We the members of Women's Institute residing on the New Credit Reserve make a request on behalf of our children who attend school.

The Council House is still used as a school house and it poorly heated as it is such a large room and naturally cold.

Also the out houses are 300 yds more or less distance from the Council House, we would like moved closer to the Council House because all thru the cold weather children have continual colds some remain home owing to prolonged colds thus delaying progress in school. More than half the children are in the primary grade.
and impossible for the smaller ones to get to the out house without an accident which make them uncomfortable rest part of the day.

The agent Mr. Winger gave us to understand that a new school would be built by this fall.

Often children gather around the stove, with coats on, and snow blowing in the windows, it's a serious problem all around and we beg of your favorable consideration in our grievances.

Mrs. Jacob King,
Secretary of

Ottawa, September 17th, 1935.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Mrs. Jacob King, Hagersville, Ont., which she signs as Secretary of the New Credit Women's Institute. You should inform Mrs. King that her letter has been received but that, as you were advised in official letter of March 20th, last, the Department was unable to secure the necessary funds this year for the erection of a new school.

Mrs. King also states that the Council Hall is very cold during the winter. If a small expenditure was made, could the room used as a classroom be made warmer? If so, you might advise the Department regarding the approximate amount that you would suggest be expended.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, requesting that four or five extra desks, of large size, be supplied, to accommodate the children attending the New Credit Indian Day School.

In this connection it is noted that there are a number of children attending whose parents are lessees on the reserve. I would point out that the Department is not responsible for providing educational facilities for their children. As there are a sufficient number of Indian children to fill the school, it is considered that you should notify the parents of the white lessees that there is no suitable accommodation for their children and that they cannot be permitted to attend the New Credit Indian School.

The Department was not aware that the children above mentioned were in attendance. The white parents should be responsible for providing for the education of their children at a school other than the New Credit Indian Day School. Dear Sir:

The Department is considering in the Estimates for 1938-39, provision for a new Day School on the New Credit Reserve.

In order that we may have full information, I would appreciate an early reply to the following questions:

(1) Is a site available, or will it be necessary to purchase a site? Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 16-1-5 of the 25th of October in connection with provision of a new Day School on the New Credit Reserve and in reply would make the following report.

(1) A site is available where the previous school stood, but in my estimation it should be moved about 100 feet north of the old site, placing it on level ground and making a better all round location, especially if there is to be a basement. The Mississauga Council own twelve or fifteen acres around this site, so no purchasing will be required on any site finally chosen, though I would prefer about 2½ acres to be fenced off definitely as school grounds, instead of an open piece of ground of many acres as at present.

In my opinion the building should face the West in order the interior of the building should get as much sunlight as possible during the fall and winter months.

(2) I do not consider the provision of living quarters for the teacher necessary, as today with motor cars and a good gravel road, access is easy for any teacher and in most ways living away from the school is preferable.
There are two wells on this site lying between the Council House (used now as the school) and the old school site. If the site recommended by me is used the same wells can be used, though the water would have to be carried a little farther, but as school consumption most of the year is not high, this would not be a great drawback.

(4) It is my opinion, construction should be made by contract, employing Indian labour if possible. If the building is to be like most schools on the Reserve, of frame construction, there are Indians on the Reservation capable of constructing it.

(5) I would certainly suggest a full basement to the proposed school, as there are many advantages to this.

I suppose there is no question that a furnace would be installed, and it is suggested the furnace room be separated from the basement so the children cannot contact the furnace in any way as they do at our No. 2 School in the Six Nations Reserve.

It is also suggested that built-in cupboards be made, rather than the moveable ones in most schools, as they would last longer and look better.

Another necessary requirement is a small, but bright and convenient room where the teacher can retire away from her charges when occasion permits. Some of our present schools have not any such accommodation, or it is a little dark room too depressing to use.

It is also suggested a basin for washing hands etc. be in the building, for where children do not go home at noon it is advisable they have an opportunity to be cleanly in their habits.

I would also recommend single graded seats be provided if possible, and all doors open outwards, as at present many open inward, and if a fire or panic occurred the children might jam the door and not get out.

At present there are 45 pupils on the roll of the New Credit School, but as the Indian population appears to be increasing steadily, it might be best to consider room for a few additional pupils.

Your obedient servant,

G. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent.

Major E. P. Randle.

In reply would advise you the subsoil
is a heavy white clay, which after about the first
three has a hard pan, and cannot exactly be called
easy digging, though there are no stones or rocks

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: New Credit Indian Day School.

With reference to your memorandum of the 31st ultimo, I am enclosing herewith, in duplicate, a blue line print of sketch plan (design A.7) for the above building.

It will be noted that whereas this type of school has previously been designed with a verandah across the entrance front, this feature has been eliminated and grade entrances introduced at a saving in cost. These entrances obviate the risk of slippery steps and that on the boys' side serves also as a grade entrance to the basement.

The estimated cost of this building is $5,900.00 and an additional amount of about $200.00 would be required to cover the cost of outside toilets, making a total amount of $6,100.00 which should be placed in the Indian Affairs Estimates for the project.
Will you kindly look over these plans and return one duly signed with any comments you wish to make.

Director.
Ottawa,
February 15, 1938.

Memorandum:

MR. WARDLE

Re: New Credit Indian Day School.

With reference to your memorandum of January 31 I enclose blue line print of sketch plan (design A.7) for the above building.

You mention $200.00 as the cost of outside toilets. In this regard I may say that for years past we have been erecting frame outside toilets at a cost of $35.00 -- $50.00 each.

When forwarding building data form with my memorandum of December 31, 1937 it was suggested that this building be erected by contract. I am hopeful that we will have some extra funds in the appropriation for the current fiscal year and, if so, it may be possible to purchase the materials required for this building. I would, therefore, appreciate if you would prepare a bill of materials. I will know definitely by the end of the first week in March whether our appropriation for this year will permit a purchase of the materials and therefore, if you have a list of the materials ready by that time, and if funds are available, the matter could be presented to the Purchasing Agent and arrangements made for securing the material and paying for it before the end of March.

Director.

Memorandum

DEPUTY MINISTER

Provision has been made in our estimates for the fiscal year 1936-37 for the erection of a new day school on the New Credit Reserve, Six Nations Indian Agency, Electoral District of Waldimand, Province of Ontario. It has been decided to erect this building by day labour. If the materials for this building were purchased before the end of March and paid for out of the current year's appropriation it would greatly assist us in carrying out our proposed building program during the fiscal year 1936-37.

Funds are available for the purchase of the material for this school from our appropriation for the fiscal year 1937-38 and I would appreciate if the Honourable the Minister would authorize the Purchasing Agent to proceed at once with the purchasing of the material necessary for this building. I enclose requisition to which is attached an order bill of material which was prepared by the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

Director.
Dear Sir:

With reference to previous correspondence regarding the proposed new Day School at New Credit it has been found possible to purchase the materials required for this building from the current year's appropriation.

It is hoped to ship these supplies in the near future. They will be addressed to you at Hagersville, Ontario. I would suggest that you get in touch with the Station Agent at that point and have him notify you when shipments arrive in order that you may arrange to accept delivery and store the materials until required. It is expected that it will be possible to commence building operations within the next month or six weeks.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hosy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major E. F. Randle,
Supt. Six Nations,
Brantford, Ont.

Memorandum: Mr. Phelan.

Re: Day School at New Credit Indian Reserve, Ontario.

I am returning herewith a tender for building materials for the above which has been received by the Departmental Purchasing Agent from Messrs Bailey and Green, Hagersville, Ontario, and which you handed to Mr. Harris for inspection together with a covering memorandum from the Departmental Purchasing Agent to Doctor McGill.

The prices quoted appear to be reasonable and fair. Some minor errors are noted in the Request for Quotations however, which should be corrected in the Purchase Order as follows:

On Page 1: 2 cubic yards Sand, the description has been transposed from an item 60 cubic yards gravel, which has been omitted. The description of sand should read "clean, sharp, screened from 1/32" to 1/8" free from earthy or vegetable matter, suitable for mortar".

As no price appears to have been asked for gravel and there is probably not time to secure one before the 31st instant, it is suggested that the purchase of the gravel and of other materials which will be required, be postponed until the new fiscal year.

The following corrections should be made in the Lumber bill of material, namely:

3 pcs. 2"x12"x14'0" $4 F.B.M. @ $45 per M. (cost $3.75)
should be changed to
3 pcs. 2"x12"x14'0" $4 F.B.M. @ $60 per M. (cost $5.00)

12 pcs. 2"x8"x12'0" 192 F.B.M. @ $15 per M. (cost $8.64)
should be changed to
16 pcs. 2"x12"x12'0" 384 F.B.M. @ $45 per M. (cost $17.28).

The changes named would add an additional amount of $9.90 to Messrs Bailey and Green's Tender making the total price $2371.80 which it is recommended be accepted.

Sir:

New Credit Indian Day School.

In discussing matters pertaining to the new school being erected at the above with Mr. McKnight who is supervising the construction on behalf of the Department, it is found there is no provision for a side-walk from the road to the School entrance.

It is my opinion that one is desirable and I would strongly urge the Department to authorize one being laid now. The roads and approaches to the School are heavy clay and in wet weather and during the thaw in the Spring, the soil clings to footwear in the worst way, but a good cement sidewalk as an immediate approach to the school would prevent much being carried into school and assist in cleanliness all round.

A sidewalk 3' wide from the road entrance to boys and girls entrance would cost $60.00, so if the Department will approve this, may this office be advised at once.

It will also be necessary to erect a fence around the school yard to prevent stock getting in, and will take two rolls (40 rods each) of wove wire fencing, plus the posts and labour. The wire will cost approximately .69¢ per rod, the posts about .20¢ each and the labour .25¢ per hour.

Mr. McKnight informs me the present arrangements call for the school to be painted only one colour on the outside, whereas all other schools have a green trim, which certainly gives a much more attractive appearance. Also the new office being reconstructed adjoining, is to be painted in conformity with most buildings on the Reservation, so may a green trim be arranged for the school.

Your obedient servant,

G. P. Russell
Indian Superintendent.

Major E. P. Randle.
EPR/CB.

Sir:

New Credit School.

Mr. McKnight who is supervising the construction of the new school at New Credit, informs me he is not responsible for the furnishings for the school but that this office is.

In view of this it is my duty to advise you though the pupils and teachers desks at present in use will be suitable for the new school, there are no suitable cupboards for either maps. There are no catalogues in this office showing school furniture of this kind, but no doubt the Department have them, and it is suggested the cupboard for books be a good size as most schools seem to lack reasonable space for placing books.

It is also not the desire of this office to be unduly critical, but as Superintendent of this Reserve I assume the Department desire to know my opinion over matters of importance under my jurisdiction and it is with regret I have to state in my opinion the new school is absurdly cramped and confined in every way as far as the school room, teachers room and lobbies for the pupils clothes etc. are concerned.

In my opinion, after allowing for seating there should be comfortable space in the rear and around the walls and between the teachers desk and the front row of pupils. This is certainly not the case in this school as when everything is in place there will be little room to move freely around.
I hope in future if schools are to be built on this Reserve some consideration will be given to this and it might be reasonable for a plan of the school to be forwarded to this office sometime prior to building operations so it would at least be possible to suggest to the Department any slight change which is considered advisable to propose.

Your obedient servant,

E. P. Rendle

Sir:

Ottawa, March 1st, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, relative to the services of the present teachers at the Oseida No. 2 and No. 3 Indian Day Schools.

In this connection I have to say that, if Miss Gast does not hand you her resignation previous to June first, next, you should inform her by that date that her services will not be required after the end of the present school year. Further, if you consider that Miss Hammond's services would be unsatisfactory for the next school year and if she does not voluntarily resign before the first of June, next, you should notify her before that date that her services will not be required next year. Sir:

Sir,

I beg to enclose a voucher for $10.00 in favour of David Williams of the Oneidas of Thames Band, for water supply for the Oneida No. 2 Day School.

In the past this has been vouchered for at the rate of $5.00 per year but Mr. Williams has been complaining that this amount is too little and says he will be satisfied with $10.00 per year.

It is a very great convenience to the school to get its water supply from Mr. Williams and some inconvenience is caused him by having the pupils going into his yard to draw water. I would recommend, for your approval, that Mr. Williams be paid $10.00 per year for the privilege of getting the water supply from his well.

I have the honour to be, Sir.

Sir:

I would beg to advise you of a few small repairs needed at the Oneida No 2, Indian Day School at this Agency and would request authority for the work to be done.

A broken latch on the girls' closet needs replacing and a urinal for the boys' closet and the cost for such urinal should not exceed a couple of dollars. A new glass 14" x 46" is needed for the front of the book case in the class room. A new black board slate four feet by three feet, six inches, is needed to replace one broken in the large black board at the front of the class-room. The teacher informed me that this was broken by a small girl and was no doubt caused by the frame that holds the whole black board to the wall becoming loose and not holding it secure against the wall.

The teacher also informs me there are only one set of keys to this school which are kept by the caretaker and another set should be secured for the teacher to have in her possession. Locks should also be placed on the doors of the closets so they may be kept closed after school hours.

Ottawa, July 16th, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, relative to the few minor repairs required at the Oneida No. 2 Indian Day School. You may arrange to have the broken latch on the girls' closet replaced and a urinal installed in the boys' closet. You may also have new glass installed in the bookcase in the classroom. You may arrange to have an extra set of keys provided for the teacher's use, and locks should also be placed on the doors of the closets and keys provided. The teacher or the caretaker should see that these closets are kept locked after school hours. After the above repairs have been completed, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

It is considered that asbestoslate, which has the same surface as slate blackboard, would be satisfactory, and we will place an order with the Government Stationery Office here to forward a piece of asbestoslate, 4' x 3'6", and when this is received you should have it installed.

Sir:

Sir;-

I would beg to advise you that the following repairs are needed at the Oneida No 2. Indian Day School, Caradoc Reserve

1. Repair broken and missing boards on outerhouse screens.
2. 1 pane of glass 6x8.
3. Repairs needed to both porch steps and painted.
4. Four door locks need repairing or replacing with new.
5. 2 dozen coat hangers needed in the cloak-rooms.
6. Interior walls of cloak-rooms need coat of paint or muresco, as they are dirty and badly marked up.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, relative to the painting of the exterior of the Oneida No. 2 Indian Day School building.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging to have the exterior painting of this building carried out during the present summer holidays. The building should be given two coats of a good grade of paint. You should arrange for the purchase of the paint, oils, etc., required, and in making the purchase you should be guided by instructions which you have received regarding purchases. Indian labour should be employed, and proper time sheets should be kept.

The total cost of the material and labour should not exceed your estimate of approximately $80.

Ottawa, June 18, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, letter received a few days ago from Mr. Vernon H. Morris. This letter, you will note, is self-explanatory.

I am anxious that you should discuss the subject matter of this communication with Mr. Morris, prior to his departure for his summer holidays. I am not, of course, sufficiently familiar with local conditions to comment upon Mr. Morris' proposals. It does seem to me, however, that they are well worth careful study. I shall be glad to have any recommendations you may care to send forward after you have had an opportunity to investigate the matter.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Nunney, Ont.
Dear Sir:

I would report that the following repairs are needed at the Oneida No. 2 Indian Day School of Caradoc Agency.

- Build a new boys out-house complete.
- Repair leak in roof of school.
- Point of the brick of chimney of school.
- Paint the ceiling of class-room ivory colour.
- Murocco the walls of class-room.
- Sand and varnish tops of class-room desks.
- Replace damaged tentest 3 foot square.
- Replace coat hooks in ante rooms.
- Replace one broken pane of glass.
- Repair fence by replacing one post.

This class-room needs painting badly and should not be left any longer and the leak in the roof should be repaired before the room is painted. The boys out-house is falling to pieces and has been repaired so often it is impossible to continue repairing it and it should be replaced at a cost of about $35.00.

The total cost of repairs at this school will run in the vicinity of $110.00.

Dear Sir,

Since the receipt of your circular letter of January, I have been thinking how this school (Oneida #2 School) could be improved.

As you no doubt know, the school facilities on this reserve are inadequate for the number of children. There are children here eight, nine and ten years of age who have never attended school.

At the present time over fifty percent of my pupils are in the primer classes. I thought that with some additional seats could accommodate thirty-five primer pupils, besides the senior classes. Furthermore if the primer classes attended only half a day I could, in this way, accommodate
seventy primer pupils, (the senior classes would come a full day). By this arrangement all the children near my school could be accommodated and the attendance act enforced—which it is not now.

This change would necessitate some new equipment—ten new desks, two primary tables, ten primary chairs and two built-in cupboards. But this expense would be much less than an new school and another teacher, and could be carried out quite well, I believe, for several years.

I should ask you to give careful consideration to this idea. If the Department considers this proposal practicable and the change can be made this summer, I would like to be consulted as to the placing of the new equipment.

I trust you will give this matter your closest attention and will let me know your decision on the matter.

My address during the summer months is given below.

Yours very truly,

Vernon H. Morris,
Victoria Harbour,
Ontario.
Dear Sir:

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 5th, enclosing a letter received at the department from Mr. Morris, teacher of the Oneida No. 2 Indian Day school of this Agency and which letter offers some suggestions as to increasing the attendance at his school so as to accommodate more children from the reserve.

Mr. Morris suggests the installation of more desks and I would advise you that the present class-room has 40 desks and the present cubic air space per child when all desks are filled is only 200 feet, whereas I am informed that the minimum is supposed to be 240 cubic feet and in view of this I would consider that no further desks be installed.

In view of the number of primer pupils attending both of the Oneida Schools, the suggestion made that primary pupils attend for half-days only should be considered, for in this way about 24 desks at each school could be reserved for senior pupils for all day attendance and the balance used for stagger classes of low or primer grades. I would consider that the small desks at present in the class-rooms would suffice, without the purchase of further equipment, for as Mr. Morris states there are pupils in the primer grades as old as ten years and all large enough to sit in desks. I would not consider the starting of kindergarten classes at the Oneida Schools in their present crowded state and therefore no need for the table and chairs.

While the suggestions of Mr. Morris could be given a trial and may work to advantage in having nearly all the children on the reserve attending school, it is decreasing the amount of time a teacher will be able to give the individual pupil and most of the teaching done will be at the desk and not from personal direction or at the board and in view of the fact that the Indians of the
the

Oneida Reserve are very backward in learning the English language (much more so than the Chippewas or Munceys) it will mean a lot of time will have to be spent on these stagger classes of primer pupils to the detriment of the pupils of senior grades.

When a census was taken some few years ago on the Oneida Reserve by the truant-officer of pupils of school age it was found there were 126 children and we have seating capacity for 76 only and at that time I recommended a new school be built and the truancy act enforced, but with no success on account of shortage of funds to build a school. It is also my belief that the education of the Oneida Reserve children would be much improved if there were four schools on that reserve so that each teacher would have in the vicinity of 30 pupils and all children forced to attend school, which would also eliminate the placing in Mount Elgin Residential School and other such schools of so many children from the Oneida Reserve who could attend a day school if such were available and which would be much to the advantage of the children than as at present.

Pending the erection of the necessary school or schools on the Oneida Reserve, the suggestions of Mr. Morris as to half-day attendance of lower grade pupils could be given a trial, without any increase in desks which would create an unsatisfactory health condition. Mr. Morris's letter is returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch.
Dept of Mines and Resources.
Ottawa, Ont.

Muncey, Ont. August 16th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Lower Muncey Indian Day School.

Please be advised that two new outhouses are needed for the above mentioned school to replace the present buildings at present in use which are of ancient vintage and are not fit for further repairs. The Public School Inspector did visit this office in connection with these buildings and those at Back Settlement school and no doubt made mention of them in his report of inspection at the school.

Mr. John Drake, Strathroy, Ont. will construct and install two new buildings at $45.00 each and it is recommended that his services be engaged for this purpose, so that these buildings will be available when school re-opens on October 1st.

The school garage which is located on the grounds of the Muncey Council hall should be removed to the grounds adjoining the school and some small repairs are needed to the fences of the school yard. The cost of these two items should not exceed $10.00.

Your obedient servant,

A.D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Oneida No. 3. Indian Day School.

The following repairs are needed at the above mentioned school and should be made before school re-opens October 1st,

4 Cedar fence posts
6 rods of ¼ foot, nine strand page wire
2 lbs staples.
1 pane glass, double diamond 25 inches square
putty and brads.
Material and labour to construct a coal bin in the basement of the school 5 feet square by 6 feet high.

The total estimated cost of the fencing, glass and coal bin should not exceed $12.00 for materials and $8.00 for labour.

The exterior woodwork of this brick school needs painting badly and it is recommended if funds are available this year. To paint it two coats with Indian labour it should not exceed $30.00, half for materials and half for labour. This painting would include the out-buildings at the school.

Muncey, Ont. August 16th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Oneida No. 2. Indian Day school.

Please be advised that the following repairs are needed at the above mentioned school,

8 New cedar fence posts
30 rods of 1/4 foot, nine strand, page wire fencing.
5 lbs fence staples.
2 new window blinds.
renew ropes on pulleys of windows in class-room to allow proper opening.
Repair steps leading to boys entrance of the school.

The cost of the material listed is estimated at $24.00 and the labour to do the work, which can be done by Indians is estimated at $12.00.

This school badly needs exterior painting and before it could be painted the building should be steel brushed to remove the old paint as much as possible, to ensure a good job being done. To paint this school two coats it is estimated the cost will run in the vicinity of $60.00, half being for materials and half for labour, employing local Indians.

One new out-house is also needed to replace one of the present structures (the other having been rebuilt two years ago) but this building is not as urgent as the fence and other repairs or the painting of the school. The cost of a new out-house would be $45.00.

Ottawa, August 19, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letters of the 16th instant, in which you seek departmental authority to proceed with certain repairs at the Oneida No. 2, Oneida No. 3, Lower Muncey, River Settlement and Back Settlement Indian Day Schools.

You can readily appreciate that it is exceedingly difficult, in times such as these, to secure the funds necessary to keep our Indian day and residential schools in a proper state of repair. I am anxious, however, that we should do our utmost to keep these buildings from deteriorating, throughout this period of national crisis.

Mr. Phelan is at this date absent from the office on holidays and I note that an amount of $450 was set apart for repairs to the schools in the Caradoc agency. I have carefully reviewed the items submitted by you and note the urgency of certain repairs that should be proceeded with at once. I am disposed to think that you should proceed with your repair program - the cost not to exceed the amount stated. This approval is given on the understanding that with the exception of the out-houses Indian labour could be employed and that you will secure the out-houses from Mr. John Drake, Strathroy, Ont.

It is important that a separate voucher, covering the cost of the repairs at each school - paint, labour, etc. - be submitted to the Department.

It is -

Mr. A. D. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.
It is scarcely necessary to state that the cost of these repairs should be kept down to the lowest possible figure. It is my hope also that you will be in a position to proceed with these repairs immediately. It might be well to state on your vouchers that Indian labour was employed in each case.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

November 11th

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find "Credit Voucher" No. 402 amounting to $79.75 in favour of the Caradoc Indian Agency Trust Account, Muncey, Ontario, and being for wages paid to Indian workmen who were engaged to do repair work at Day Schools of the Caradoc Agency as was authorized in your letter 7-6-5 of July 7th, 1941.

The funds advanced by Departmental cheque No. 50901 were to be used in effecting repairs at the Back Settlement, Bear Creek, Oneida No. 2 and Oneida No. 3 Schools but other repair work of a minor nature was urgently needed at some of the other day schools and I used some of the funds for this purpose which I trust will meet with approval.

There is an unexpended balance of $20.25 on hand here at the present time. In your recent letter 7-7-8 of November 7th I was granted permission to expend an amount of $10.00 in cleaning out and repairing the drain at the Oneida Teachers' residence and I would wish to be advised if the funds remaining from this $100.00 advance i.e. $20.25, could be used to pay the Indian who does this work on the drain.

If this is approved the drain expenditure will be paid and any balance remaining on hand will be returned to the Department along with Receiver General returns.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken

Muncy, Ontario,
November 26th, 1941

Dear Sir:

The Reverend Jones, Anglican minister of Caradoc Agency, has approached this office requesting permission to use the Oneida #2 Indian Day School, in which he wishes to hold semi-weekly meetings at night in connection with Young People's church activities.

Mr. Jones stated that this matter was brought to the attention of Mr. Phelan some time ago. Apparently Mr. Morris, former teacher of this school, discussed the matter with Mr. Phelan, with the result that Mr. Phelan gave permission.

The meetings are, as stated, to be held twice a week, in the evenings. Mr. Jones states that he would be there to supervise, or I would designate some responsible person to act in his place. He also informed me that the Young People's organization would assume responsibility in the event of damage to school property. I am not in favour of this procedure, as past experience has shown that these Young People would in all probability damage the property unless strictly supervised, and it would be hard to prove whether the Young People or the school children had done the damage, if window panes were broken and other similar offences were committed; the organization would include young people from fifteen to twenty-five years of age who are on the Reserve who have a reputation of being more or less irresponsible and rowdy.

There would also be the matter of cleaning up the school after these meetings which the Young People would no doubt neglect, and considerable fuel would be burned if the school were to be kept open two nights a week for the meetings. Sometime ago I believe Mr. Morris, the former teacher, opened up the school for the purpose of holding these meetings, and it ended up with them holding dances in the school, and when it was discovered that dances were being held, Mr. Moore, the former Agent, prohibited the use of the school for such purposes in the future.

I would wish to be advised if the Department authorize using the school for the purpose above mentioned, and your early reply would be appreciated, so that I may advise Mr. Jones as to the Departmental decision.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken
Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Ottawa,
December 4, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo with reference to application which you have received to use the Oneida No. 2 Day School for semi-weekly meetings of the Young People's Society.

I have discussed this request with Mr. Phelan but he has no recollection of any application for permission to use this building having been made by Mr. Morris.

If it is the intention to simply use the building for social purposes the Department cannot grant any permission.

However, if the meetings are intended to be for purposes of study I feel that they should be encouraged and, in this event, the necessary permission can be given on the distinct understanding that Rev. Mr. Jones attends each meeting and is responsible for seeing that no damage is done to either the building or its contents.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. M.W. McCracken,
In Charge Indian Agency,
Muncey, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find vouchers Nos. 451, 452, 453, 454, 456, 457, 458, amounting to $130.35, in favour of T. B. Escott Co., Ltd., being payment for noonday lunch materials at the seven Indian Day Schools of Caradoc Agency.

The expenditure made in purchasing materials to supply hot lunches to the pupils of these schools was made in accordance with instructions contained in Departmental letter 7-5-5 of November 22nd, 1941. Purchases were made from a firm on the approved list, and quite favourable prices were procured. The teachers will commence the preparation of the hot lunches for the pupils in the near future, when the weather becomes colder. At the present time the weather is mild, and hot lunches are not required.

December 5th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-6-5 of November 15th, 1941, advising that the unexpended balance of cheque #5990, which was to be used for payment of wages for repairing Indian Day Schools, may be used to pay for expenditures incurred in cleaning out and repairing the drain at Oneida teachers' residence. The drain at this school has been cleaned out and satisfactorily repaired at a total cost of $10.00, and which work was done by Indian labour.

Enclosed please find Credit Voucher No. 465 in favour of Caradoc Agency Trust Account, amounting to $10.00, and being the expenditure made on the drain at the Oneida teachers' residence. Duplicate receipt is attached.

To date there is an unexpended balance of $10.25, which will be returned to the Department along with our future Receiver-General returns. It may be that some of the schools will require minor repairs, and if so, this unexpended balance will be used to pay for same, and I would wish to be advised if that does not meet with the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken

January, 7th 1942.

Dear Sir:

In reporting matters of interest at the Caradoc Agency during December I would advise as follows:

Indian day schools were in operation during the month but were closed on December 19th for the Christmas vacation. The teachers have been provided with vocational training materials as well as supplies to enable them to prepare hot noon day lunches for the pupils during the winter months. A filtered well was recently dug on the grounds at the Oneida No. 2 School. The water in this new well is proving satisfactory both in quantity and purity.

M.W. McCracken, In Charge,
Caradoc Agency.

I have made a tour of the Indian Day Schools of the Caradoc Agency and submit herewith a report as to repairs that I think are at this time necessary.

ONEIDA NO. 2

1. Stove in dilapidated and dangerous condition.
2. Desks are very dirty and in need of repair.
3. Interior decorating.
4. Outside steps.

Approximate Cost

Stove - $50.00
Desks - Repairing, cleaning varnishing
Material - $12.00
Labour - $20.00
Total - $32.00

Interior Decorating -
Material - $45.00
Labour - $50.00
Total - $95.00

Steps Material - $10.00
Labour - $10.00
Total - $220.00

This report is submitted with a view to laying before you for consideration, repairs which I think are necessary and should be given every possible consideration. For convenience the listed repairs are in order of priority. You will appreciate the fact that we are already in the second month of summer holidays. It would therefore be appreciated, should you consider the suggested repairs, that this Office be advised as soon as possible.

Geo. W. Down, INDIAN AGENT.
Ottawa,

Mr. G.W. Down, Indian Agent, Muncey, Ont.

You may also purchase a new stove at a cost not exceeding $50.00.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Attention Col. Neary:

URGENT

During a recent visit to Oneida No. 2 School I found conditions much overcrowded and beyond the capacity of the teacher. During September forty-one pupils were on the roll and while the school was necessary to provide full seating accommodation, this was provided. In October the roll revealed an increase of eleven. A registration check revealed that the condition was created by an enrolment of beginners; in other words six year olds, caused undoubtedly by the Family Allowances regulations which is, by the way, a step forward and points to a higher interest in education and an effort to get our Indian children started at an early age.

Accommodation, as you know, is not, in any of our one-room Day Schools, adequate for efficient teaching but until the condition is corrected we must provide temporary arrangements. In an effort in this particular case, to find a solution I discussed the problem at length with Mrs. Frida Johnstone and Mrs. Lillian Lockwood, both teachers of the Oneida Reserve, and I was told that a staggering of classes had been ordered. To my mind this is not a solution and both teachers agreed. It is merely an evading of the question and a failure to accept responsibility for which we could be, as in the past, severely criticized. Both teachers felt that a better plan could be arranged. The result of our discussion is as follows:

"A proposal to rent the Agricultural Fair Hall which is in close proximity to Oneida No. 2. If this can be arranged I think I have sufficient blackboards, seats and books to establish the extra classroom.

It would then remain to secure an extra teacher. In this I do not think I would have any great difficulty. If the arrangement is approved Mrs. Johnstone would assume charge of perhaps Grades 3, 4, 5 and 6 totalling 26 and the extra teacher would assume control of Grades 1 and 2 totalling 25."

In the meantime Mrs. Johnstone is quite willing to assume the present pupilage for a limited time; in other words until arrangements for the new set up can be made, but if it should drag on longer than expected...
we decided that a better plan would be to send the beginners home for perhaps a few weeks rather than have the higher grades staggered to the extent that they would only receive one-half day's schooling a day.

These are merely suggestions and are submitted for your consideration. If you approve of the renting of the Hall and the hiring of an extra teacher please advise as soon as possible. I will then do my best to correct the condition without delay. It may be necessary to request a few details to convert the Hall into a comfortable classroom but they will be minor and suit our purpose until arrangements can be made for increasing the school's classroom accommodation.

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Since the dictation of this letter I have been assured by Fair Board officials that the Agricultural Hall may be made available at any time.

Oneida #2.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Oneida #2 Indian Day School.

At the present time this school is operating as a two room school with Mrs. Johnstone in the classroom building and Mrs. Holdsworth teaching in the basement of the Baptist Church across the road.

Mrs. Johnstone has a bright personality and her handling of the upper grades is quite satisfactory. Here again the children tested well and spoke out clearly and distinctly. The natural music ability and artistic talent of the Indian children is appreciated by the teacher and she has done much to develop their talents in this respect and in this way to arouse their interest in the school.

In the main building no teacherage is provided but the structure is sound and should last for a good many years yet. It has no furnace and is heated centrally by a stove. The interior has been recently painted and fenestration is satisfactory. Electricity has been installed and this makes quite a difference on dull days.

Mrs. Holdsworth is teaching the junior grades in the Church basement and while having a more aggressive personality than Mrs. Johnstone, the children seem to like her and respond well.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Memorandum:

MR. HOLLER,

Onida No. 2 Indian Day School,
Moraviantown Indian Day School,

Included in our 1949/50 Estimates is the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of a one-room school and teachersage on the Onida No. 2 Reserve in the Canadian Agency and $14,000.00 for a similar school at Moraviantown in the Moravian Agency.

It has been recommended by the Regional Supervisor, Mr. Morris, and by Indian Superintendents Hall and Spence that these schools be erected by day labour with the Departmental Purchasing Agent buying all necessary materials.

It is recommended by our field officials that we employ Mr. Frank Mahler, of Dalhousie, Ontario, as foreman carpenter at the Onida No. 2 Indian Day School at the rate of $1.50 per hour. Mr. Mahler has acted as foreman-carpenter for us in the erection of the four-room Indian Day School at Mount Elgin and the one-room Indian Day School at Rock Settlement. He has trained a group of Indians on these two projects and we feel he will be entirely satisfactory for the erection of the Onida No. 2 School.

For the Moraviantown School it has been recommended that we employ an Indian as head carpenter. He is Fred Stonefish of Thamesville, Ontario, and is reported to be a first class carpenter. He would be paid at 65¢ per hour.

As Mr. Mahler has had considerable experience in following departmental specifications and in the building of our schools, it has been recommended that he go to the Moraviantown
School once a week to supervise and inspect the construction of the new school there. The schools are only 35 miles apart. This will give the Moravian Indians the necessary guidance in the following of the blueprints and specifications and will help Mr. Indian Superintendent Spence, who feels that his Indians can do a satisfactory job.

Therefore, I would recommend to you that both these schools be erected by day labour and that you approve the hiring of Mr. Mahler and Mr. Stonefish on the terms indicated above.

Director.

Re: Proposed new Oneida #2 School,
Caradoc Indian Agency, Muncey, Ontario.

I would recommend building this structure by day labour because of the employment provided for the Indians and the low cost to the Department, as these men may be employed for .70¢ to .85¢ per hour.

Mr. Mahler, the proposed foreman, is most co-operative and his charge is not too high. He has done an excellent job on the new Back Settlement School, which is practically completed. Moreover, he can and is willing to over-see, or supervise, the building of the proposed new School at Moraviantown.

The truck and cement mixer at the Caradoc Reserve can also be used at Moraviantown.

I am asking for Plan #365 since Hydro is already installed in the other Oneida #2 Classroom. There is an adequate supply of water on the grounds and one pressure system could supply both buildings. Inside toilets could also be used by pupils of these buildings and removal of the out-buildings would provide more playground space, which is badly needed. Furthermore, the better living accommodations would attract good teachers, who are always in demand.

F. L. Hall

Memorandum:

Colonel B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: New School -
Moravian Indian Agency.

Superintendent Stuart Spence has already submitted a recommendation to your office that the construction of the new school on the above Reserve be done under the supervision of a capable Indian carpenter-foreman with Indian labour.

I interviewed the Indian Superintendent Spence has in mind and he appears to be trustworthy and talks as if he has sufficient knowledge to undertake this work.

I would suggest that Mr. Spence's proposals be approved and that the Purchasing Agent be requested to obtain all the materials for early delivery. I understand he has already had the cellar excavated. So that his job may proceed without interruption, I would recommend that he be authorized to purchase locally the lumber required to construct the forms for the cellar. The cost should not, in my opinion, exceed $100. Arrangements have been made with Superintendent F. L. Hall, of Caradoc Indian Agency, to send his cement mixer to the Moravian Indian Reserve to be used in running the cement for the foundation. It is, therefore, imperative that the cement be bought and delivered at the earliest possible date.

The work on the above school, as suggested in my memorandum of even date on file 417-9, should be supervised occasionally by Mr. Mahler, the carpenter-foreman, and if this is done, it should be possible to avoid a number of building difficulties as he, to my way of thinking, is capable and familiar with the construction of this type of school.

J. E. Morris,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for the Province of Ontario.
