May 3, 1949.

Mr. F.L. Hall,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
Muncey, Ontario.

Oneida #2 Indian Day School.

Ministerial approval has been given to the hiring of Mr. Frank Mahler of Delaware, Ontario, as foreman carpenter for the construction of the Oneida #2 Indian Day School at the rate of $1.50 per hour.

In view of his experience in following Departmental specifications, and in the building of our schools, it has also been agreed that he will go to the Moraviantown Indian Day School once a week to supervise and inspect the construction of the new school there. Mr. Fred Stonefish of Thamesville, Ontario has been employed as head carpenter there and Mr. Mahler has given he and his workcrew the necessary guidance and supervision in the following of the blueprints and specifications of plan 865.

Seven hundred bags of cement have already been ordered for the construction of this school, and the bill of materials will be forwarded to the Departmental Purchasing Agent today. The Purchase Order should reach you in the near future. If necessary, we can authorize local purchase of $100 worth of form lumber so that the foundation can be started.

As you are aware, plan 865 with specifications is to be followed in the construction of this building. You have already received an accountable advance of $1000 for wages for this project, and I would suggest that you request an additional amount in the near future.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: Water for Oneida #2 School

A thorough investigation of the water supply at the above school shows it to be inadequate. The supply thus far has been from a filter well which is not good at best.

However, at a distance of 2600' from the school, situated on Indian land, is a spring which flows throughout the year. The supply besides being apparently sufficient would seem to be safe for human consumption. We have had a local contractor do some investigating and he estimates a cost of approximately $3000.00 to put in a system to bring the water to the school. This would include a power line to the spring, pipe line, pressure system, pump house etc.

Having discussed the matter with Mr. Morris, we decided to request the Departmental Engineer be sent to investigate and give his report.

If money could not be found for this project at once it could be included in our estimates for next year.

Mr. Morris has first hand information on this matter and will discuss it with you.

Yours truly,

Fred Hall, Sup't.

Re: Plumbing Contract for Oneida # 2 School

We refer to your letter dated September 13th under file # 417-5 (El) wherein you more or less approved the tender submitted by the Delaware Plumbing and Electric, but asked that we endeavour to secure other tenders.

Rhame Bros. Limited of London, Ontario, seemed interested so we supplied them with plans, specifications and a list of the plumbing materials bought under Purchase Order No. 44660. A copy of their reply, in part, is self-explanatory.

"I have checked into the details of this and find that there is very little that we will have to supply other than the actual labour of installation. When I wrote you, I realized that some of the materials had been purchased, but I did assume that we would be able to include at least the greater part of the soil pipe and fittings, water pipe and fittings, etc.

Under these circumstances, I do not think that we can give you a quotation on this contract. At the present time, we
we have a considerable amount of work under way. I think that you will readily agree with me and understand our situation in that it would not be good business, not fair to our other customers to do this job, which would take a considerable amount of time as far as travelling is concerned, as well as actually doing the work, and on which we are only able sell labour. As you know doubt realize, in our business, profits on labour only, are negligible."

In view of these circumstances we seek approval of the tender submitted by Delaware Plumbing and Electric.

Yours truly,

Fred Hall,

The unsatisfactory conditions and results of the day schools in the Cariboo agency necessitated an inspection and remedial measures. 164 children were enrolled during the past fiscal year and the average attendance, but 85 - a percentage of 46. The average salary we have been paying is $607. These facts are indicative of two reasons for the lack of progress, (1) bad attendance, (2) unqualified teachers.

In October I spent three days visiting the schools and the public school inspectors. The only really qualified teacher is Miss McDonald, at Oneida No. 3. Miss MacArthur, at Muncey, is very successful and worthy of another trial. The other four teachers - Miss Brown at River Settlement, Miss Graham at Bear Creek, Mr. Doxtator at Oneida No. 2 and Mr. Fisher at Back Settlement - are unqualified and should be released at the first opportunity.

I returned to the reserve after a week-end at Moraviantown and Walpole Island and met the Indian parents, the chiefs and councillors, missionaries and others, at a general meeting in the Chippewa Council Hall. I explained that conditions were unsatisfactory and asked for the reasons. The parents and other Indians took quite an interest and were practically unanimous that there were but two reasons: (1) poor attendance, (2) unqualified teachers. The Chief, councillors and parents promised to do everything in their power to better the attendance and I assured them that the Department would install qualified teachers at the first opportunity. When pressed for my meaning in this connection, I explained that the teachers at the River Settlement and Bear Creek Schools could be changed practically at once, (end of the calendar year) as teachers could secure boarding accommodation in the vicinity, and that the Back Settlement and Oneida No. 2 teachers could be changed as soon as residences for qualified teachers could be provided.

I am including in the Estimates for 1925-26, as Important Day School Needs, a residence for the Back Settlement School, a residence (2 teachers) for Oneida No. 3 and No. 2. I also assured them that the only classroom building which was really unsatisfactory (that at Oneida No. 2) would be replaced at the first opportunity. A new building is now in the course of erection on a day labour basis.

I am arranging for better equipment in these schools and, in an effort to make them attractive, am providing some libraries and some articles for group games. At a later date it may be necessary to offer prizes for best attendance and to also organise the reserve into school districts so that a real interest will be aroused.
Extract from Teacher's Annual Report on the Oneida No. 3 Indian Day School for the year ended March 31, 1925, ONTARIO.

REMARKS.—

These people need a great deal of technical training. To avoid the taking of the children from the reserve some sort of consolidated school is needed in which pupils could be taught, possibly technical work and something more than entrance work. I think the results would justify the expenditure. I find myself handicapped at times by irregular attendance. A school on this plan would largely overcome this difficulty. They need a school which trains and helps them to earn a living, a practical education as well as a book or theoretical study. With regard to the entrance pupil, he is a Grade IV boy who, quite possibly, will cover the 2 years work. However I do not wish to crowd him unduly and cannot say until Easter when we hope to have completed the work on all subjects, whether his rating will be sufficiently up to standard to permit him to try the entrance or not. At present his average is fairly good but I am not at all sure that it would be in his best interests to let him stop school at this time. He is only 13 years old in December but, as the nearest High School is nine miles away, he will not be able to get any further unless the teacher at this school can handle the High School subjects here. It is for such boys that I covet a consolidated school on the reserve. Advice in this matter would be very acceptable.

Catherine C. MacDonald,

Madam:

I wish to refer to that portion of your annual report on the Oneida No. 3 Indian Day School relative to technical and secondary training. I note that you recommend a consolidated school on the reserve, and I have to inform you that the Mt. Elgin Institute is for the purpose of giving vocational instruction as well as academic training to the Indian pupils of the vicinity. I note that you have a 13-year-old boy who may try his Entrance at the close of this academic year. The Department does not favour secondary training for Indian children in reserve schools. We consider that high school work should be taken in competition with white children and in the regularly constituted high schools and colleges of the province. When a bright and promising student is ready for advanced work the Department, upon the recommendation of the teacher and the Indian agent, would give favourable consideration to a small tuition grant for a year or two, to assist the parents to meet the expense attendant upon the pupil's studying in a white community.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

You have my resignation. I'm sure in your files at present. I sent it at the end of May. But may I endeavour to explain some things to you as a means of self-satisfying the thing in me that calls for fair play?

I was told that my work has never given satisfaction because of my lack of discipline, that there were repeated reports sent to you from the agent and inspector who have the authority over me; that there were reports back from your headquarters strongly criticizing my work; that I was too friendly with the Indians; and that I was at the time in the balance, and liable to lose my position. I was naturally shocked and hurt and resigned immediately after learning these
things from the agent himself who had helped to cause my troubles.

It seems to me that I owe it to my own self respect to explain something to you, Mr. Terrier, who for some reason, I've come to think of as a friend because you so kindly helped me out with extra cheques.

My idea of discipline is not that a school should be run on soldier-like tactics. Those days are past. The present trend of education on discipline is one where the teacher tries to understand the child and rule him wisely but as much as possible by appealing to that which is best in him, not by outward force. I know that it's a high ideal. But I undertook to learn to understand these people. I have been interested in all church and community work and I know that it has been good for the young people on the reserve here to have a teacher who took a personal interest in their welfare. It helped me and it helped them. My discipline was the kind that any educational authority would call the best.
I know there were things broken at school. But I do not think that there was any more damage there than in any other school. Most of the things could easily have been remedied without any necessity for a report about them. And none of them were any different than the accidents that occur in any school.

I came here with a desire to help the people. I have always been interested in church work. I have always intended to become a Deaconess. This place gave me glorious opportunities for doing that kind of work. I know that it did not please the man in authority over me. He did not encourage, but simply made fun of my "missionary" idea. I cannot help feeling that he was unfair in his reports about me.

However, I want you to know that I did my conscientious best, and that God blessed my work and influence. The things I have done will leave a mark for good on these people because I did them for the sake of Him whom I serve.

Yours very faithfully,

Acknowledging your letter of July 6th with reference to the marginal-named. When I was in Ottawa I did state that I expected all teachers at present employed would be returning for duty next year. Upon returning to my Office many rumours were in circulation and a general spirit of unrest among the farm workers prevailed, centering, apparently, around salaries. However, your letter refers to Mrs. Johnstone only. The only answer I can give at this time is: it is rumour.

You are aware, of course, that the teachers are on summer vacation and perhaps feel that they may take their own time as to whether or not they wish to return for duty. I have not yet had an opportunity of contacting Mrs. Johnstone for verification. I did, however, speak to Mr. Alton Ryckman, our Farm Instructor, Mrs. Johnstone's father, and although he did not commit himself he said that she had been offered $1400 to teach at Komoka, approximately three miles from her home. To date this is the extent of my information. As soon as I am able to contact Mrs. Johnstone personally I will advise accordingly.

Mrs. Johnstone's movements evidently travel very fast, in a roundabout way, before becoming official knowledge. While we are on the subject of school
teachers I might also mention Mrs. Thompson of Back Settlement School. It is also rumoured that she is dissatisfied with her salary and also intends leaving if satisfactory adjustment is not made. In the West Middlesex Inspectorate it is reported that there are expected to be 75 Public School vacancies and that certain officials are making every effort to "pinch off" qualified, successful teachers. Both Mrs. Thompson and Mrs. Johnstone are among the best we have. However, if we are unable to offer the salaries we shall be unable to retain their services. A report will follow on each case as soon as I have made personal contact.

I submit, herewith, for your consideration an application as received from Mr. Jamieson for Oneida No. 3 Indian Day School.

Mr. Jamieson is an Oneida Indian of the Caradoc Agency, not too co-operative toward the Indian Affairs Branch; and an arrested T.B. patient. He is the father of Mrs. Virginia Schuyler who, you will recall, taught school at River Settlement, Caradoc Agency, and later at Kettlepoint.

Personally, I do not approve; neither do I think the majority of the parents with children going to school would accept him favourably. All pupils formerly attending No. 3 have been taken care of either at No. 1 or No. 2 and I think, rather than upset the children, his application might be refused on the grounds that it would be unwise to disturb the pupils at this time; also, the fact that he does not possess the necessary qualifications as required by the present day Board of Education.

I am not adverse to an Indian teaching in one of our Day Schools but, knowing this man and his family as I do, I am sure it would only lead to unpleasantness not only with this Office but many of the parents concerned. However, the final decision is yours.

SCHOOL NEWS

A WEEKLY NEWS SHEET FOR THE CHIPPEWA, NUNCEY AND ONEIDA RESERVES.

September 7

Our teacher-training course has proven quite worthwhile. All of the teachers took an active part in the programme and received considerable help from the exchange of experience. In addition to this we were privileged to hear from three School Inspectors and the Director of Art for Ontario. We shall all enter upon the term's work with a greater enthusiasm and a clearer idea of our task and its opportunities.

The Indian Affairs Branch was represented by Mr. Doucet, a teacher of wide experience, who outlined the main objectives in Indian education. He was unable, without first consulting other members of the Department, to satisfy all our questions, some of which are very important to our plans here. Many smaller details have been attended to, but we are not yet sure how many grades or pupils we are to have in the senior school. We have been assured of Grade IX and X and have urged that at least VII and VIII be added. We are to be able to bring also any pupils who would particularly benefit by the type of work to be done here. These measures are for this year, since by next year, with the new school and the bus problem solved, a more extensive programme is expected.

We have just learned that Mr. Conron, of Oneida #3 is not coming back. This is most disappointing, especially since it has given us no opportunity to secure a teacher in time for Monday. It simply means that the pupils of that section will not be able to start school on Monday, but will wait until they hear from me. Mr. Doucet intends to do everything possible to send us a teacher immediately, but we know that teachers are scarce, it may mean some delay.

The other five schools are expected to open on Monday morning, with your former teachers in charge. For the present it would be wise for all pupils, up to and including Grade VIII, to plan on getting started at their own schools. In consultation with the parents and teachers, those who will be allowed to come to the Senior School will be selected during the coming weeks, or when definite word has been received.

Parents please note that no child is to be started to school who is less than 6 years old, except those who will be 6 before December 31 of this year. Until the number of pupils is known, there can be no exception to this rule.

E.B.K. Joblin.

I am afraid my report on the usefulness and capabilities of Mrs. George, recently appointed teacher at the Oneida No. 3 School, must be adverse. I discussed the matter with Mr. Joblin but he did not appear to be much concerned. You will recall that some person recommended Mrs. George as a teacher, but my first interview with her revealed that she did not possess any teaching qualifications. In fact, her work along this line had been limited only as a Governess to some small children. However, it was decided that she might be given a term of probation.

Mr. Smith, the Public School Inspector, was in my Office today and we discussed the matter very thoroughly. He found conditions as I did, a complete lack of control with little or no teaching experience; in fact we both definitely agreed that the situation is impossible and that the only course open was to recommend that her services be dispensed with at the very earliest opportunity. If you have any other suggestions, please outline them.

Yours truly,

Reference is made to your letter of December 5th with regard to the teacher of Oneida No. 3 Indian Day School and I agree with you that the teacher proposition is difficult, also that it is preferable to keep the school open if only for a matter of discipline and keeping the children off the roads. However, conditions at this school are beyond description and I did not wish to enlarge upon Mrs. George's inability to maintain even some semblance of order and control. I have never called that I could imagine myself entering a school; and Mrs. George cried and openly admitted that the children were entirely beyond her control. Mr. Smith and I discussed the matter at some length and I assumed that he would, in his report, go into a little more detail. However, when I received your letter I also received one from Mrs. George which is attached and is self-explanatory. I can only suggest that we accept her resignation and endeavour to secure another teacher immediately following the Christmas holidays.

The water conductors are still unreplaced. There is no water available. The pump is still broken and well has not been cleaned. The closets are not in good condition, there being no fasteners on the doors and no urinal in the boys.

There is no wood or coal. The furnace is not in good repair and, in place of using it there is a small stove in the class-room.

Ottawa, November 8, 1920.

Sir,

Mr. P. J. Thompson, Public School Inspector, in his report of inspection of the Onsada No. 3 Indian Day School, states that the water conductors are still unreplaced and that there is no water available, as the pump is still broken and the well has not been cleaned. He also states that the closets are not in good condition, there being no fasteners on the doors. There is no wood or coal. The furnace is not in good repair, and in place of using it there is a small stove in the class-room. The Inspector states that the school will have to be discontinued unless wood is provided.

With reference to the conductors from the eaves-troughs and the repairs to the pump I beg to refer you to official letter of June 7th, last, in which you were asked to report as to the repairs required. No reply seems to have been received to this latter and you will, therefore, be glad enough to take immediate steps to have the well cleaned and the pump repaired. Should a new pump be required you may purchase the same, but competitive prices should first be obtained before the purchase is made.

The closets should be cleaned out and placed in good condition and fasteners should be placed on the doors.

The repairs needed to the furnace should be attended to and it should be put in good condition for the winter.

You should take immediate steps to have the quantity of wood or coal required delivered at the school, competitive prices being obtained by you before making the purchase.

You should attend to all the above matters as soon as possible and all labour and other expenses in having the above repairs made should be performed as cheaply as possible. The Department will leave these matters in your hands to have these repairs attended to at an early date. Properly certified accounts, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred, to which should be attached a memo showing the prices obtained by you for any materials required in making the repairs and for the fuel.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
For Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Thos. McGookin, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.

Sir,

In reply to your letter No.7-7-5, of the 8th inst., in regard to repairs to Oneida No.3 day school.

I beg to say that the necessary repairs to the water conductors are being made, the closets are being cleaned out, and a sufficient amount of stove wood is on hand, delivered same day as Inspector Thompson visited school.

In regard to furnace being out of order, I have had two local men examine it and they have failed to find the trouble; it will be necessary to bring a man from London to have it repaired, this it was not considered advisable to do, this winter, in face of the fact that it has been impossible to get coal here at any price, so that the furnace could not have been used in any case, in the meantime the class room is heated by a box stove, which makes the room very comfortable. The furnace will be overhauled and put into working order for next winter, when it may be possible to get coal.

In regard to the pump, I have been doing my best to get it working, but the men who were to do the work—Williams & Walker—have not started operations yet, I have got in touch with a well operator in St. Thomas, who is coming to give me an estimate on the job. Owing to the high wages offered to Indians this season it has been impossible to get a local man to do anything.

This work will be completed as cheaply and expeditiously as possible.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Onside No. 3 Indian Day School, again draws attention to the condition of the furnace. He states that this furnace has not been used for three or four years, owing to some needed repairs, and that the school is heated by a small stove which does not keep the building warm in cold weather. He also states that the closets are in bad condition - the doors being broken off - and that the cover on the well should be repaired.

The condition of the furnace has been drawn to your attention on several occasions, but it does not appear that any action was taken in the matter. You should also give the approximate cost of any repairs which you would recommend be made. You will be good enough to arrange to have any repairs required made to the closets, and they should be cleaned and put in good condition. This work can be done during the coming summer holidays.

The Inspector states that there are wide cracks in the cover of the well, which allow the water to fall back into the well, carrying with it any impurities that may be on the cover. If you consider that a new cover should be placed on the well, or that the present one could be put in good repair, you may arrange to have this work done. No unnecessary expenditure, however, should be incurred for the purpose.

ARCHITECT.
In reply to your letter No.7-7-5, of July 14th, in reference to repairs to furnace at the Oneida No.3 day school.

I beg to say that I have had a man look over this furnace and extensive repairs will be required to put it into working order, even when repairs have been completed it is doubtful if it will be a success. This furnace is altogether too large for the purpose.

I would recommend, for your approval, that a larger wood stove be provided for this school. This, I believe, would be much more satisfactory and less expensive. In the case of the furnace it would require more attention, to get satisfactory results, than a janitor can be relied upon to give. Sir:

In reply to your letter No.1-7-5, of the 17th ultimo, regarding the heating arrangement at the Oneida No.5 school.

I beg to say that this school is heated by a box stove, the furnace has not been in use for some years, it was found to be not satisfactory, the janitor would neglect to attend to it after school hours, with the result that the fire would be dead in the morning and the class room quite cold when school opened. The teacher, Miss Tena Brodie, made application to have a large stove installed to be used instead of the furnace.

The furnace requires overhauling and a new cold air pipe attached, if grates suitable for burning wood were put in, the furnace could be used satisfactorily, it could be lighted each morning and the room heated much more quickly than with coal.

The approximate cost of this work would be $50.00, a workman from St. Thomas would be necessary, if the work is to be done properly.

Regarding the interior decorating, this work was done about two years ago and is quite fresh still, very few white schools are in as good condition as this one, it is painted a light green color, the teacher prefers a buff shade which would be brighter, but I would not recommend the re-painting at present, it seems an unnecessary expenditure.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

I shall be pleased to have a report from you as to whether you would recommend that the painting of the school building as suggested by the Inspector be carried out. The other repairs referred to by the Inspector should, however, receive your attention, and you should arrange to have the water conductor repaired, also the plaster in the schoolroom and the broken windows and closets repaired. Sir,

I beg to advise you that the following repairs are urgently needed at the Oneida No.3 Day School,-

The closets are very old and in a dilapidated condition; they were built many years before the present school building and have been repaired so often that further repairs are a waste of time and money. I would recommend that two small closets be built.

The brick work at the two front entrances has broken away and if allowed to further decay, the porches will be in danger of falling down.

The inside wall between the classroom and the two cloak rooms is badly cracked; the plaster on this wall has been repaired several times but, it appears, the closing of the doors cause a vibration which loosens the plaster, part of which has fallen down. I am of the opinion that this wall should be beaver boarded.

The interior requires painting and also the outside window and door sashes. These repairs would put the school building in good condition. If the Department approve of these repairs, tenders will be asked for and submitted; the work could be done during the summer holidays.

November 17, 1928.

Dear Mr. Elliott:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, enclosing copy of communication from Mrs. Ethel Abram, of Muncey, in which she asks that the Department assist in providing hot lunches for the children attending the Oneida No. 3 Indian Day School. I may say that at the present time this question is under consideration, and, a few days ago, Mr. Indian Agent McGookin was asked for a recommendation. You will understand that, if we provide a hot lunch for this school, four others in the same Agency will have to be considered, and it is just possible that many other schools in the Province will be affected.

There is no question of the advisability of a hot lunch for school children. However, when the parents are able to provide it, there is doubt concerning the expediency of having it done by the Department. After all, one of our chief aims is to make the Indian independent. I have found the best solution is to ask the parents to give the children a little solid food for the noon hour, which is supplemented by soup, cocoa or milk, provided by the Department and prepared by the older girls under the supervision of the teacher.

Ottawa, February 18, 1929.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant inclosing account amounting to $234.65, in favour of Messrs. Hamilton & Stott, for repairs to the furnace of the Oneida No.3 Day School, and also for new eyes troughing for the said School.

In reply I return the said account herewith, and I have to inform you that the Department considers it very high. The estimate of the cost for repairs to the furnace was $135.00, whereas the cost as per account submitted is $174.65. ST. THOMAS, February 21, 1929.

Mr. Thos. McGookin,

Dear Sir:

In explanation of the Muncey School Furnace repairs account. These items on the account for Material are Invoice prices or more particularly what the material cost us.

The freight charges are for the freight cost including telephone and telegrams, this is estimated from a period of time as you see by the explanation that the cost of the castings and the telephones is more than is charged in your account not considering the freight charges of the other material.

The twenty per cent. item is a profit item we would think we are entitled to. The transportation charge is based on a mileage basis and in this connection includes the freightage of the combustion chamber and of the other material from St. Thomas to Muncey.

The time you will find is itemized on a separate slip. You will remember when our Mr. Stott was speaking to you in your Office of the cost of repairs that he told you it was hard to estimate a cost and this will be principally on account of not being able to estimate the labor.

You will see that the Combustion chamber and the shaker handle were two items which we did not know had to be replaced, which of course entailed more labor in connection with the replacement particularly of the Combustion Chamber.

Yours very truly,

HAMILTON & STOTT.

JES/AT.
Muncey, 25th February, 1929.

Sir,

Referring to your letter No. 7-7-2 of the 18th instant, in connection with repairs to the furnace at the Oneida No. 5 Day School.

I beg to enclose an explanatory letter from Hamilton and Stott, plumbers who made the repairs, which I think will make the matter clear.

The prices charged for parts required for furnace are the cost prices at the factory, and can be checked up by reference to the Gurney Foundry Company's price list.

The item of $4.44 is made up of freight, $3.15 as per attached receipts and two telephone calls to Toronto at 75¢ each, a total of $4.65. An itemized statement showing the workmen's time is attached.

When looking over the furnace and giving an estimate of the approximate cost of repairs, a new combustion chamber and shaker handle were not included, but when the furnace was pulled to pieces it was found that these were necessary, the cost and labour of installing the combustion chamber added additional cost to the estimate submitted.

The work was completed in a very satisfactory manner, the furnace, which had been out of use for the past ten years, is now giving excellent service and will be good for another ten years.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Oneida No. 3 Indian Day School, states that the plaster in the cloakrooms and in the classroom requires repairs, also that the classroom, halls, etc., are in need of redecoration. He also states that a portion of the school fence requires repairs.

I have to request that you will furnish a report regarding the redecoration and repairs required, giving an estimate of the cost of any work which you recommend be carried out. This matter should receive your early attention in order that, if it is decided to have any work done, it can be carried out during the coming summer holidays.

The Inspector further states that the basement is very untidy, as all the winter ashes are still in it, and that a number of window panes are broken. He also states that the latch on the girls' closet is broken. Please arrange to have the cellar cleaned out and placed in good condition, and any panes of glass required put in the basement windows, and a new latch placed on the girls' closet. The water conductors need some repair, if the brick work is not to be injured. Cement tops should be put on the well. Water comes into the basement, possibly from the water conductors. There is a pile of ashes in the basement which should be removed.
Ottawa, June 14, 1930.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Oneida No. 3 Indian Bay School, states that the water conductors require some repair, if the brick work is not to become injured. He also states that water goes into the basement, possibly from the water conductors. The Inspector suggests that a cement top be put on the well, and states that there is a pile of ashes in the basement which should be removed.

Please report what repairs you would recommend be made to the water conductors; also regarding a cement top for the well. If you recommend that any action be taken, you should give an estimate of the cost. You should take early action in having the ashes removed from the basement.

Your obedient servant,

A. W. MacKinnon,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.
Sir:-

Re: Oneida No 3. School.

I would beg to advise you that the following supplies and repairs are needed at the Oneida No 3, Indian Day School, Caradoc Reserve,

- Fire grates for a Oxford 626 coal furnace.
- Pamper K.A. 50 for Oxford furnace.
- 6 panes of glass for basement windows.
- 2 complete frames for basement windows.
- 6 wire screens for protection of basement windows.

- Floor and steps on the South porch need renewing and painting.
- 1 pair of door knobs.
- 2 new door locks for classroom and cellar doors.
- Lightning rods need resailing to outer walls of school.
- Alarm clock for class room needed, the present clock not being worth repairing.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter 7-7-5 of June 14, with reference to the repairs of the Onieda No. 3 school and would advise that 3 water pipe conductors are required for this school, which should be in the vicinity of 8 ft. long and made secure on tripods to throw the water away from the school wall, so it is too hard to have water conductors remain on the school in reach of children or cattle who destroy and break these as soon as installed.

On the north end of the school there are 2 hollow places which hold water in from the conductors and which should be filled and rounded up with earth. These no doubt cause the water to leak into the cellar. The school pump repairs were included in my letter to you of June 13, and I do not recommend concrete top for the well.

In view of the fact that these wells are surface wells and need cleaning at occasional periods, which could not be done if concrete tops were put on, I would recommend some new planking for the present top as well as an extension to the water trough to make it long enough to carry the water from well top so it will not soak back in.

The total cost of these repairs, along with others mentioned in my letter of June 13, should not exceed in the vicinity of $75.00 all told. I would advise you that the pile of ashes has been removed from the cellar.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.

Sir:

The members of the Mothers' Club of No.3 School wish to have you intercede for us in asking the Indian Department to help providing a hot mid-day lunch in the school, which will not only help the children but the teacher as well.

Many of our Indian folk are not able to help and that is why we are asking for help. We would be very glad if the Department would aid us in our work, and we the mothers, will do all we can to have the children attend school regular.

The teacher has a good attendance at present but circumstances will not allow us to have our children attend regular if we do not get ahead with our new organization.

The Teacher's reports of last winter explains to us that she had fairly good attendance at beginning of the season and when cold weather settled the attendance was cut down to eight on account of hard circumstances through lack of clothing and provisions in the homes of the children.

Hope you will give this a fair consideration.

Yours,

President of Mothers' Club

"Mrs. Ethel Abram"

Dear Mr. Elliott:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, enclosing copy of communication from Mrs. Ethel Abram, of Muncey, in which she asks that the Department assist in providing hot lunches for the children attending the Oneida No. 5 Indian Day School. I may say that at the present time this question is under consideration, and, a few days ago, Mr. Indian Agent McCookin was asked for a recommendation. You will understand that, if we provide a hot lunch for this school, four others in the same Agency will have to be considered, and it is just possible that many other schools in the Province will be affected.

There is no question of the advisability of a hot lunch for school children. However, when the parents are able to provide it, there is doubt concerning the expediency of having it done by the Department. After all, one of our chief aims is to make the Indian independent. I have found the best solution is to ask the parents to give the children a little solid food for the noon hour, which is supplemented by soup, cocoa or milk, provided by the Department and prepared by the older girls under the supervision of the teacher.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Sir,

I would beg to advise you that on making a recent inspection of the Onaida No. 3 Indian day school Caradoc Agency, I found a very crowded situation, there being 42 pupils present with a seating accommodation of only 35 and have been advised by the teacher that this condition has existed for some time and that owing to the fact that the majority of these pupils are in minor grades it is impossible for her to give them the attention they should get and also have the discipline necessary for Indian education.

I also found five windows broken and the hot air pipe of the furnace torn down, a number of the school desks loose in the class-room, the outside doors of the school with loose hinges and broken locks and on questioning the teacher as to the discipline she has maintained with the pupils to allow such damage to be done and she informed me that she has a number of larger pupils who are attending that are not there to learn and are very disturbing factors in the disciplining of the school, and also that she is unable to watch and control such a large number of pupils.

I also found that although 8 tons of coal and about 6 cords of wood have been supplied this school this winter, it will be all gone within a week and in short this school is in a very unsatisfactory condition, and although the teacher is very diligent and sincere in her work, she has not the proper control of her pupils, which in my mind is caused by her taking too large an interest in other works and which are not her duties and that she should give her services for teaching and teaching only.

During the coming summer, to save expenses I would consider it much better if the use of this school's furnace was eliminated and a small furnace installed in the class-room, which would cost in the vicinity of $60.00 but would be saved in the cost of fuel in one winter and I am quite sure that such a stove would give sufficient heat for the class-room of this school.

Owing to the present condition of the doors, at this school, I would also recommend that two new doors be purchased and two new locks installed on these doors, also five panes of glass will have to be put in at once. I would also wish your authority to expell from this school any children 15 or 16 years of age whom it is not possible for the teacher to discipline and who are not learning but are creating a bad influence in the class-room.

Secretary,
Dept. of Ind. Affs.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,
A.D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 5, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, reporting on the crowded condition of the classroom at the Oneida No. 3 Indian Day School and stating the damage that has been done to the windows, desks, etc.

Regarding the overcrowding in the classroom, I have to say that it is noted the teacher is unable to keep oversight and control the large number of pupils, also that some of the older pupils are a very disturbing factor in the discipline of the school. The Department does not wish to deprive any child under the age of sixteen years from attending classes, but, in cases where they do not conform to discipline, they should not be permitted to attend. The teacher and yourself should discuss the matter of the attendance of the older pupils and give notice to those who do not conduct themselves properly that they are to discontinue attendance. The Department will leave the matter of refusing permission to attend in the case of those older pupils who are creating a bad influence in the classroom in the hands of yourself and the teacher. You should inform the teacher that it is expected she will devote her full time to the teaching duties during the regular classroom period, also that she should keep proper control and discipline over the pupils.

Regarding the repairs, etc., required, I have to say that you may arrange to have the five broken windows repaired, the hot air pipe of the furnace replaced, and any school desks that are loose in the classroom refastened. You may also arrange to install two new doors, with a suitable type of lock on each. You may also arrange to purchase any further fuel required for the present winter's use. Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the above authorized expenditures should be forwarded.

The matter of a change in the present furnace has been noted. Our funds for the next fiscal year will be extremely limited, and it is doubtful whether any alteration in the heating system can be made. You might, however, draw this matter to the attention of the Department next summer.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.

Ottawa,
May 17, 1944.

Mr. G.W. Down, Indian Agent, Munsey, Ont.

It has been brought to the attention of the Department that the Oneida No. 3 School is not very comfortable in the winter. I understand that this building is heated by stoves, although there is stated to be a furnace in the basement. The Department would appreciate it if you would inspect this building at once and let me know at the earliest possible date what action could be taken to make this building more comfortable for the winter.

R.A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
I wish to refer to your letter of May 17th with reference to the heating of Oneida No. 3 Indian Day School, and after an inspection it would appear that your informant has been misinformed. Apparently there was a furnace installed but I am told it was dismantled some ten or fifteen years ago, for what reason nobody seems to know. Since that time a stove has been used with apparent satisfaction until last year when Mrs. Johnstone, the teacher, complained of the school being uncomfortably chilly. I therefore requested, and you approved of, a new stove at a cost of $50.00. The $50.00, however, had to be returned because a stove with increased heating capacity could not be purchased, and the merchants advised that they could not hope to replace a stove of the size and capacity required until after the War.

Before suggesting the installation of a new furnace, if available, I would want to know the reason why the previous unit was taken out; you probably have something on School files referring to this. In any case, to replace any type of heating unit at the present time, even if available, creates a problem. One of the penalties of the rural dweller today is the complete indifference to his most necessary requirements. Tinsmiths and plumbers, in fact all mechanics, are at a premium, and do not hesitate to advise that, owing to gas control, they are not interested in jobs that entail a trip of 10 or 15 miles a day. I contacted a plumber a few days ago in connection with this school and he advised that he was too busy to even think of it. Personally, I do not see what action can be taken at
the present time unless the services of a competent heating mechanic can be secured, and the type and size of furnace made available, although there is perhaps one alternative. The ceiling in the classroom is very high and there is a possibility that the present heating unit would work more efficiently if the ceiling were lowered. This could be done by putting in new joists and a false gyproc ceiling. I have not yet estimated the cost of such a job, neither do I claim that it would correct the condition but if the idea meets with your approval I will estimate the cost and endeavour to have the work done during the summer holidays.

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Muncey, Ontario,
Nov. 29, 1946.

It is with regret that I have to report another outbreak of window breaking at the Oneida No. 3 School. This time a concentration was made, particularly on storm windows and basement windows. This is very unfortunate and makes it difficult to keep the school warm and comfortable; and to add to my difficulties, I am at present unable to obtain glass.

The R.C.M.P. and the local Indian Constable are working in an endeavour to learn the names of the guilty ones, but again it is very difficult. A few names have been given but, of course, they all deny any part in the destruction. I am convinced that the depredation is the work of school children and I am wondering what you would want done, should we secure definite proof of damage. Personally, I prefer to warn the parents in a manner which will leave no doubt that any further depredation on the part of their children will meet with court action.

Yours truly,

Geo. W. Down,
INDIAN AGENT.

Dep't of Mines & Resources,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF D. G. SMITH, SCHOOL INSPECTOR
on his inspection of ONEIDA NO. 3 Indian Day School - dated Nov.28/46
Original on 7-7-6

The general condition of the school both with regard to accommodations and to progress is very unsatisfactory.

All the basement windows have been broken out. The grates in the stove are broken and cross pieces of iron have been put on top of them to prevent the coal from falling through. This means that the ashes cannot be shaken out and on the day of inspection the fire died out. The floor is cold on account of all the basement windows being out and in this weather the school is not fit for use, without a good fire. It was most uncomfortably cold on the day of my visit. During the past two weeks there has been considerable wanton destruction around the school. This includes the breaking of the glass in all the storm windows which were stored in the basement and the destruction of a door in the basement. I understand that this matter is being investigated. There is no knob on the classroom door and children cannot get in from the outside. The pump is not in working order.

This building is of brick construction, and solidly built. All outside sashes and window frames need painting; also repairs to outside steps.

The ceiling of this school is too high, and the walls are badly in need of repair. In fact the entire interior should be remodelled with one of the modern types of wallboard, and three new blackboards installed.

Sir:

I would beg to inform you of the request of the two Indian Day School teachers residing at the residence on the Oneida of the Thames Reserve, that their residence be supplied with the following, complete sanitary closet for the bathroom, mirror for bathroom, a new three burner oil stove for the kitchen, a small oil-cloth rug for the kitchen floor, 12 cups and saucers, 6 knives and forks, complete set of curtains for the building, pane of glass for the storm doors, wire screens for the windows.

The old sanitary closet in use has rusted out and cannot now be used, but the teachers have available an outside closet 30 feet from the building that is in good shape if kept clean and locked by them. The present oil stove used for cooking is depleted and of no use and the teachers have had to rent one for some time and a new one should be supplied. There is a mirror in this office I would turn over to these teachers as it is not in use here. An oil-cloth rug 6 feet square is needed in the kitchen, as are 8 cups and saucers and 6 knives and forks. The present curtains are worn out and the teachers have been using their own and curtains should be supplied, a good grade purchased by the yard being best. The present wire screens on use in the window have rusted through and are needing replacing and the small extending type at small cost would be sufficient. Two small panes of glass should be replaced in the storm doors to put them in shape for the future.

Your obedient servant,

A.D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 31, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th instant, relative to the request of the teachers residing in the residence on the Oneida of the Thames Reserve to be supplied with the equipment as mentioned for the use of the residence.

With reference to the request for a sanitary closet for the bathroom, it is considered that the outside closet should be satisfactory for their use until next fall at least. You might have this outside closet thoroughly cleaned and, after this has been done, it is expected that the teachers, themselves, will see that it is kept in good condition. If there is no lock on the door, you may have a suitable lock installed, and the key should be kept in the possession of the teachers, who should see that the closet is kept locked.

You may arrange for the purchase of an oil stove for cooking purposes. This should be obtained as cheaply as possible, having in view the supplying of a stove of a satisfactory type.

Regarding the mirror, it is noted that you can supply one from your office, which is not in use, and I would request that you hand same over to the teachers.

You may arrange for the purchase of an oilcloth rug, 6' square, also 6 cups and saucers and 6 knives and forks.

You may purchase the quantity of curtain material required. It is considered that the teachers could make up the curtains and have them installed. You may also arrange to have the wire screens on the windows replaced. It is noted that you consider it would be satisfactory if the small extending type of screens were supplied. You may also arrange to have any panes of glass required replaced in the storm doors.

After the above authorized expenditures have been incurred, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.

Re: Teacher's Residence, Onside Reserve, Ontario.
Suspected Breaking & Entering of.

On the 8th instant a complaint was received from the Indian Agent's office that the above noted premises had been entered.

Investigation revealed that Harry James, local store-keeper and William Farrow, carpenter, had placed new screens on the windows of the residence. On their arrival they had noticed that the back door was open; one bed appeared to have been slept in and an alarm clock was set for five A.M. and was running.

It was believed that whoever was responsible for this act was making a practice of spending the night there and with this in mind a patrol was made to the residence in the early A.M. of the 9th, 10th and 11th instants and observations made without success.

Enquiries made from the Agent's office disclose that certain repairs had recently been made to the building and it is thought that when the repairman completed the job he left and failed to notice that the catch on the Yale lock was not in the lock position.

It is more than likely that whoever entered the building did so to take shelter from the inclemency of the weather. This presumption is further amplified as whoever entered did not do so for gain as there are dishes, linens, coal oil lamps and other miscellaneous articles of value which have not been touched and which would be considered as valuable loot to an Indian if entry had been made with that in mind.

It may be stated that during the School vacation periods the schools and Teacher's residence is kept under observation while making general patrols of the Reserves and the doors and windows inspected periodically.

The doors and windows have been securely locked so that entry cannot be made except by force.

Sir,

One of the priests of this diocese, who has charge of the Indian missions in the Lake Superior District, has written me, with reference to the appointment of teachers for the Catholic Indian schools. Mr. Connolly, the agent of the Department at Port Arthur, informed the missionary father, that he was instructed by the Indian Department at Ottawa, not to permit anyone to teach in the schools for the Indians, without having at least a Third Class Certificate; and that the testimony of knowledge and good conduct hitherto given by the missionary, would not suffice. Now I desire to protest most strenuously against this violation, on the part of the Department, of an agreement made with my predecessor Rt. Rev. Bishop James. According to this agreement the appointment of teachers for the schools of our Catholic Indians, was left to the Bishop or his deputy, the priest in charge of the mission. The priest has in all cases selected the best teachers that could be obtained for the small salary given, viz.: Two Hundred Dollars ($200) and in some cases Two Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($250). How you can readily understand, that if the priest engaged only such teachers as held Third Class Certificates, most of the schools would be closed, as very few teachers with this qualification could be found willing to instruct.

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter of May the 9th, No 153811/1, addressed to Rev. L. Dugas, I must say that I am in charge of the Pic Reserve school.

When Miss Harrison was transferred to Lake Helen school Nepeigon, I wrote then to the Depart and gave the reasons which necessitated the transfer.

When Miss Harrison arrived at Pic Nov. the 3rd 1906, all the Indians, without notifying me of their intentions, had all gone away in the woods, except two families. For three weeks she had only one little girl 8 years old to attend school and she had only three pupils until Xmas time. Few days after New Year 1907 all the Indians went away again; not a single pupil to attend school, as you may see by the returns of that period. The poor woman lived all alone on the Reserve at 3 miles from the station of Theron Bay.

She would have returned to Montreal if she could, but she had no money to do it. Then, by charity for the poor woman, I had a log building put up at Montezambert by the Indians who had come there to work (it cost me $30.00 to get windows and lumber for walls) and Miss Harrison continued to teach there with an attendance of 10 to 16 pupils.
at summer time she returned to Pie Reserve where she had as many as 26 pupils present sometimes.

I have tried my best to induce those Indians to remain on their Reserve, but they pretend that they cannot find their living on the Reserve.

I had another teacher ready to come if she was wanted, but I did not intend to expose her to pass through the same troubles as Miss Harrison. Indeed after the picking berries and fishing was over, the Indians all went away again last fall, and they have not returned yet to the Reserve.

If I see any chance to reopen that Pie school, I will be most anxious to apply for a teacher.

Yours in Xst

Rev. W. Lamarche, J.F.,
Nepigon, Ont.
